<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 119, 379, 144]]<|/det|> # Cambridge IGCSE™ <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 170, 195, 201]]<|/det|> CANDIDATE NAME <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 221, 175, 250]]<|/det|> CENTRE NUMBER <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 210, 425, 255]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[620, 220, 720, 250]]<|/det|> CANDIDATE NUMBER <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[735, 210, 905, 255]]<|/det|> <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 178, 292]]<|/det|> ## PHYSICS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 276, 905, 292]]<|/det|> 0625/52 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 260, 316]]<|/det|> Paper 5 Practical Test <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[707, 300, 905, 316]]<|/det|> October/November 2023 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[760, 325, 905, 341]]<|/det|> 1 hour 15 minutes <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 371]]<|/det|> You must answer on the question paper. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 700, 401]]<|/det|> You will need: The materials and apparatus listed in the confidential instructions <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 230, 434]]<|/det|> ## INSTRUCTIONS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 808, 560]]<|/det|> INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units. <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 220, 603]]<|/det|> ## INFORMATION <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 604, 729, 636]]<|/det|> INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 40.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ]. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[710, 644, 905, 839]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 96, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 648, 89]]<|/det|> In this experiment, you will investigate the period of a pendulum. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 688, 121]]<|/det|> Complete the following instructions, referring to Fig. 1.1 and Fig. 1.2. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[227, 128, 767, 375]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[285, 388, 356, 406]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[601, 388, 670, 406]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 419, 593, 437]]<|/det|> A pendulum has been set up for you as shown in Fig. 1.1. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 450, 146, 468]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 450, 828, 467]]<|/det|> The distance \(d\) is measured from the bottom of the clamp to the centre of the bob. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 482, 618, 500]]<|/det|> Adjust the length of the pendulum until \(d = 50.0 \text{cm}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 496, 918, 529]]<|/det|> Displace the bob slightly and release it so that it swings. Fig. 1.2 shows one complete oscillation of the pendulum. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 527, 789, 545]]<|/det|> Measure, and record in Table 1.1, the time \(t\) for 10 complete oscillations. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 543, 918, 575]]<|/det|> Calculate, and record in Table 1.1, the period \(T\) of the pendulum. The period is the time for one complete oscillation. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 574, 579, 591]]<|/det|> Calculate \(T^2\) and record the value in Table 1.1. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 590, 555, 607]]<|/det|> Write the unit for \(T^2\) in the column heading. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 605, 920, 622]]<|/det|> [3] <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 636, 541, 653]]<|/det|> Table 1.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[134, 662, 863, 747]]<|/det|>
\(d/\mathrm {cm}\)\(t/\mathrm {s}\)\(T/\mathrm {s}\)\(T^{2}/\)
50.0
100.0
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 764, 146, 781]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 764, 551, 781]]<|/det|> Repeat the procedure in (a) using \(d = 100.0 \text{cm}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 764, 920, 782]]<|/det|> [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 740, 120]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 633, 89]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate the resistance of a wire.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 581, 121]]<|/det|>
Complete the following instructions, referring to Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[175, 128, 819, 336]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[467, 352, 534, 371]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 384, 146, 403]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 384, 299, 403]]<|/det|>
Close the switch.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 415, 448, 434]]<|/det|>
Measure the current \(I\) in the circuit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[643, 415, 920, 434]]<|/det|>
<form>I = ....................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 447, 146, 465]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 447, 631, 465]]<|/det|>
Place the sliding contact at a distance \(l = 10.0 \text{cm}\) from \(\mathbf{B}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 477, 920, 512]]<|/det|>
Measure, and record in Table 2.1, the potential difference (p.d.) \(V\) across the length \(l\) of resistance wire \(\mathbf{BC}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 524, 297, 543]]<|/det|>
Open the switch.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 555, 920, 590]]<|/det|>
Calculate, and record in Table 2.1, the resistance \(R\) of \(10.0 \text{cm}\) of the resistance wire using the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[470, 599, 527, 630]]<|/det|>
\[R = \frac{V}{I}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 636, 465, 654]]<|/det|>
where \(I\) is the current recorded in (a).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 667, 299, 685]]<|/det|>
Close the switch.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 698, 740, 717]]<|/det|>
Repeat the procedure using \(l = 20.0 \text{cm}, 30.0 \text{cm}, 40.0 \text{cm}\) and \(50.0 \text{cm}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 730, 297, 747]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 92, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 633, 89]]<|/det|> In this experiment, you will investigate the cooling of hot water. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 581, 121]]<|/det|> Complete the following instructions, referring to Fig. 3.1. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[245, 129, 749, 297]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 308, 534, 327]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 339, 146, 358]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 339, 645, 358]]<|/det|> Use the thermometer to measure the room temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 369, 922, 388]]<|/det|>
\(\theta_{\mathrm{R}} =\) ....................................................... <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[918, 370, 920, 388]]<|/det|> [1] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 401, 144, 420]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 401, 180, 420]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 401, 920, 435]]<|/det|> Pour \(200 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water into the beaker. Place the thermometer in the water in the beaker. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 447, 920, 481]]<|/det|> Record in Table 3.1 the temperature \(\theta\) of the hot water at time \(t = 0\). Immediately start the stop-watch. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 494, 920, 528]]<|/det|> Continue recording the temperature and the time in Table 3.1 at 30 s intervals until you have seven sets of readings. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 510, 920, 528]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 541, 180, 560]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 541, 559, 560]]<|/det|> Complete the column headings in Table 3.1. <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 572, 541, 590]]<|/det|> Table 3.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[312, 598, 685, 817]]<|/det|>
\(t/\)\(\theta /\)
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 819, 920, 838]]<|/det|> [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 72, 96, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 866, 91]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the effect of changing the colour of light on the focal length of a lens.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 101, 633, 123]]<|/det|>
The focal length \(f\) of a lens is given by the equation \(f = \frac{uv}{(u + v)}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 138, 920, 171]]<|/det|>
The distance \(u\) is the distance between an object and the lens. The distance \(v\) is the distance between the lens and the image that is formed on a screen.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 185, 920, 219]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment to investigate the effect of changing the colour of light on the focal length of a lens.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 233, 473, 250]]<|/det|>
You are **not** required to do this experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 263, 537, 281]]<|/det|>
The following apparatus is available to the student:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 295, 304, 311]]<|/det|>
· illuminated object

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 310, 660, 327]]<|/det|>
· a selection of coloured filters to change the colour of the light

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 326, 292, 342]]<|/det|>
· converging lens

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 342, 217, 357]]<|/det|>
· screen

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 357, 253, 373]]<|/det|>
· metre ruler.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 387, 740, 405]]<|/det|>
Other apparatus normally available in a school laboratory can also be used.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 418, 324, 435]]<|/det|>
In your plan, you should:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 450, 707, 467]]<|/det|>
· draw a labelled diagram to show the arrangement of the apparatus

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 465, 920, 497]]<|/det|>
· explain briefly how you would do the investigation, including the measurements you would take

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 496, 920, 528]]<|/det|>
· draw a suitable table, with column headings, to show how you would display your readings (you are **not** required to enter any readings in the table)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 527, 648, 544]]<|/det|>
· state how you would use your results to reach a conclusion.

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[437, 73, 561, 88]]<|/det|>
# BLANK PAGE
